title: John: Bilateral Lower Limb Weakness in a Young Adult with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
clinical_history: John is a 24-year-old graduate student who presents with a progressive history of bilateral lower limb weakness and atrophy over the past 4 years. He reports frequent tripping, 'slapping' of his feet on the ground, and difficulty ascending stairs. There is a visible deformity in his feet described as high arches (pes cavus) and hammertoes, which have become more pronounced. The patient complains of distal calf muscle wasting, with particular weakness in foot dorsiflexion and eversion, resulting in bilateral foot drop. He also notes numbness and tingling in his feet and lower legs, but has less significant symptoms in his hands. He denies bowel or bladder dysfunction. John recently began using ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) due to unsteadiness and to improve gait. There is no history of trauma. Family history is positive for similar symptoms in his father and paternal aunt.

nprs.affected_area: Distal lower limb (ankle and foot dorsiflexors and evertors)
General leg fatigue and aching after prolonged walking/standing

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged walking, running, stair climbing, uneven surfaces, cold weather (increases numbness/paresthesia); standing for extended periods increases leg fatigue.
picture: [insert image of bilateral lower limb muscle wasting, high arches and hammertoes]
easing_factors: Rest, elevation of legs, use of AFOs to prevent foot drop, supportive footwear, stretching exercises for calves and intrinsic foot muscles.
past_history: Mildly delayed motor milestones (walking at 16 months); minor sprains due to frequent ankle rolling as a child.
medical_history: No other chronic illnesses reported. Vaccinations up to date.
medications: Occasional acetaminophen for aching (less than weekly), vitamin D supplementation.
personal_history: Non-smoker, occasional alcohol use, lives independently in student housing, highly motivated academically, though increasingly self-conscious about gait. Family history of neuropathy.
imaging: Nerve conduction studies reveal slowed velocities consistent with demyelinating neuropathy. No MRI to date.
